Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Energy Harvesting Wireless Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to establish fundamental performance limits and the ensuing design principles for wireless communication networks composed of devices that operate with energy harvested from the environment. These energy harvesting systems are envisioned to enable energy self-sufficient, energy self-sustaining, perpetually operating wireless networks, and untethered mobility. As such, they will enable new societal, medical, environmental, monitoring/surveillance and safety applications which are otherwise difficult or impossible with conventional battery-powered operation. These applications range from enabling perpetual remote environmental monitoring and surveillance, structural monitoring to on and in-body networking for health monitoring, medical diagnosis and treatment.

The project identifies the randomness, intermittency, and causality of energy availability, as well as the uncertainty about the energy states of the transmitters at the receivers, as new ingredients to be incorporated in determining the fundamental performance limits of energy harvesting wireless communication systems, and seeks to determine the information theoretic capacity of an energy harvesting link and the accompanying optimum coding and transmission scheme by incorporating energy harvesting constraints into the information theoretic capacity formulation. The project also seeks to identify the information capacity of multi-user, multi-hop, cooperative energy harvesting networks, as well as incorporating practical issues such as imperfections in storage and retrieval of energy to/from battery, leakage of energy over time, etc., into rigorous information theoretic capacity formulations. Furthermore, the project will make connections to estimation, privacy and security by investigating state amplification, state masking and secure data transmission problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Use of energy harvesting technologies in communication systems will reduce the use of conventional energy, reduce carbon footprint, enable energy self-sufficient self-sustaining autonomous network operation, and enable new applications (such as surveillance, security and medical applications) which are otherwise impossible with conventional battery operation. As such, these technologies are expected to lead to environmentally friendly operation of existing communication networks and enable new applications with significant societal impact. This project determined the ultimate capacities of such systems, and also developed schemes and methodologies that achieve or approach these capacities. The techniques developed in this project will be useful in the design of future energy harvesting wireless communication systems.


The major technical outcomes of this project include the determination of the information-theoretic capacity of an energy harvesting communication link, and the development of the corresponding capacity-achieving communication scheme. In addition, this project developed optimal and near-optimal online power control algorithms to be used in multi-user energy harvesting systems, such as broadcast channels, multiple access channels, two-way channels, channels with processing and decoding costs, and channels with general utility functions. These algorithms use only causal knowledge of the energy harvesting process and can be implemented in practice. This project theoretically proved the near-optimality of the proposed algorithms using mathematical bounding techniques.


Educational and outreach outcomes of this project include incorporation of research results into graduate-level teaching at the University of Maryland, offering tutorials at conferences and graduate-student summer schools, and publishing  several expository and review articles on energy harvesting communications intended for general audiences.


Human development and training outcomes of this project include training of several PhD students here at Maryland and at Penn State (our collaborative partner in this project) on energy harvesting communications, wireless communication theory, wireless networking, and network information theory. These PhD students have had the opportunity to interact and collaborate with their peers and faculty at another institution through this project, which enhanced their learning and research experiences.
